Question Text: Which of the following is an example of a network layer (layer 3) protocol in the five-layer TCP/IP model?
Choices:
a. IP
b. Ethernet
c. UDP
d. TCP
LLM Explanation: IP (Internet Protocol) is a network layer (layer 3) protocol in the five-layer TCP/IP model. It is responsible for addressing, routing, and delivering packets across network boundaries. Ethernet operates at the data link layer (layer 2), while UDP and TCP are transport layer (layer 4) protocols.
URLs: ['Kurose, J., & Ross, K. (2017). Computer Networking: A Top-Down Approach (7th Edition). Pearson.', 'Forouzan, B. A. (2017). TCP/IP Protocol Suite (4th Edition). McGraw-Hill Education.', 'https://www.ietf.org/rfc/rfc791.txt']

Question Text: Which of these is an example of something that works on the application layer (layer 5 of the five-layer TCP/IP model)?
Choices:
a. A router
b. A browser
c. UDP
d. An ethernet cable
LLM Explanation: A browser operates at the application layer (layer 5) of the TCP/IP model. It interacts directly with the end user, allowing them to access and view web pages. Routers work at the network layer to direct data packets, UDP is a transport layer protocol, and Ethernet cables are physical layer components for wired network connections.
URLs: ['Computer Networking: A Top-Down Approach, 7th Edition by James Kurose and Keith Ross', 'TCP/IP Illustrated, Volume 1: The Protocols by W. Richard Stevens']

Question Text: Which layer of the five layer TCP/IP model deals with cabling and connectors?
Choices:
a. The network layer
b. The transport layer
c. The physical layer
d. The application layer
LLM Explanation: The physical layer of the five layer TCP/IP model deals with the physical transmission media, including cabling and connectors. It defines the electrical and physical specifications for devices, and the relationship between a device and a transmission medium, such as a copper or fiber optical cable.
URLs: ['https://www.geeksforgeeks.org/layers-of-osi-model/', 'https://www.comptia.org/content/guides/what-is-the-osi-model', 'https://www.cisco.com/c/en/us/support/docs/ip/routing-information-protocol-rip/13769-5.html']

Question Text: Which level of the TCP/IP five-layer model does a router operate on?
Choices:
a. The data link layer
b. The transport layer
c. The application layer
d. The network layer
LLM Explanation: A router operates at the network layer of the TCP/IP five-layer model. The network layer is responsible for addressing, routing, and delivering packets between different networks. Routers use IP addresses to make decisions about where to forward packets to reach their destination network.
URLs: ['Computer Networking: A Top-Down Approach, 7th Edition by James Kurose and Keith Ross', 'CCNA 200-301 Official Cert Guide, Volume 1 by Wendell Odom']

Question Text: On which layer are Ethernet standards and some wireless technologies operating?
Choices:
a. The network layer
b. The transport layer
c. The physical layer
d. The data link layer
LLM Explanation: Ethernet standards and some wireless technologies operate on both the physical layer and the data link layer. The physical layer defines the electrical and physical specifications for devices, including the layout of pins, voltages, cable specifications, hubs, repeaters, network adapters, and more. The data link layer defines the format of data on the network, providing data link functions such as addressing, error notification, and flow control. Ethernet and wireless standards like 802.11 Wi-Fi specify both the physical connectivity and the data link protocol.
URLs: ['Computer Networking: A Top-Down Approach, 7th Edition by James Kurose and Keith Ross', 'CCNA 200-301 Official Cert Guide, Volume 1 by Wendell Odom']

Question Text: Which of these allows connections from many devices and inspects the contents of ethernet protocol data?
Choices:
a. A hub
b. A collision domain
c. A cable
d. A switch
LLM Explanation: A switch allows connections from many devices and inspects the contents of Ethernet protocol data. It operates at the data link layer (Layer 2) of the OSI model. Unlike a hub, which simply replicates data to all ports, a switch intelligently directs data only to the intended recipient based on MAC addresses, reducing network traffic and improving performance.
URLs: ['https://www.cisco.com/c/en/us/products/switches/what-is-a-network-switch.html', 'https://www.comptia.org/content/guides/what-is-a-network-switch']

Question Text: What does LAN stand for?
Choices:
a. Local area network
b. Little area network
c. Large area network
d. Locally available network
LLM Explanation: LAN stands for Local Area Network. It refers to a computer network that interconnects computers within a limited area such as a home, school, computer laboratory, office building or group of nearby buildings.
URLs: ['https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Local_area_network', 'https://www.cisco.com/c/en/us/products/switches/what-is-a-lan-local-area-network.html']

Question Text: What's a router?
Choices:
a. A physical layer device that prevents crosstalk
b. A device that knows how to forward data between independent networks.
c. A more advanced version of a switch
d. A physical layer device that allows connections for many computers at once
LLM Explanation: A router is a network device that forwards data packets between computer networks. Routers operate at the network layer (Layer 3) of the OSI model. They use headers and forwarding tables to determine the best path for forwarding the packets, and they use protocols such as ICMP to communicate with each other and configure the best route between any two hosts.
URLs: ['https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Router_(computing)', 'https://www.cisco.com/c/en/us/products/routers/what-is-a-router.html']

Question Text: Which of these is a server?
Choices:
a. A device operating on the data link layer that connects many devices together and inspects ethernet protocol data
b. A device that forwards data between multiple networks
c. Something receiving data from something providing data
d. Something providing data to something requesting the data
LLM Explanation: A server is a device or program that provides data or services to clients that request them. In a client-server model, the server is the entity that provides data to the client requesting that data. Therefore, options c and d both describe characteristics of a server.
URLs: ['https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Server_(computing)', 'https://www.cloudflare.com/learning/network-layer/what-is-a-client-server-model/']

Question Text: What kind of wiring is in cables that communicate in voltage changes that are received by the receiving device as ones and zeros?
Choices:
a. Fiber
b. Aluminum
c. Gold
d. Copper
LLM Explanation: Copper wiring is used in cables that communicate in voltage changes received by the receiving device as ones and zeros. Copper is an excellent conductor of electricity and is commonly used in networking cables like Ethernet. The voltage changes in the copper wire are interpreted as binary data (ones and zeros) by the receiving device.
URLs: ['https://www.webopedia.com/definitions/copper-cable/', 'https://www.techtarget.com/searchnetworking/definition/Ethernet']

Question Text: What modulation type is used for computer networks?
Choices:
a. RJ45
b. Simplex communication
c. Line coding
d. Line crimping
LLM Explanation: Line coding is the modulation type used for computer networks. Line coding is the process of converting digital data into a format suitable for transmission over a physical medium, such as copper wires or fiber optic cables. It involves representing the binary data using voltage or current levels, or light pulses in the case of fiber optics. Line coding ensures reliable transmission and helps in clock recovery and error detection.
URLs: ['Computer Networking: A Top-Down Approach, 7th Edition by James Kurose and Keith Ross', 'Data Communications and Networking, 5th Edition by Behrouz A. Forouzan', 'https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Line_code']

Question Text: What is the difference between full duplex and half duplex?
Choices:
a. Half duplex occurs when hubs are in use; full duplex occurs when switches are in use.
b. Full duplex allows communications in two directions at the same time; half duplex means that only one side can communicate at a time.
c. Full duplex is a form of simplex communications.
d. Full duplex is slower than half duplex.
LLM Explanation: Full duplex communication allows data to be transmitted in both directions simultaneously, meaning both devices can send and receive data at the same time. In contrast, half duplex communication only allows data transmission in one direction at a time, with devices taking turns sending and receiving. The choice of full or half duplex is not directly related to the use of hubs or switches, and full duplex does not imply simplex communication or slower speeds compared to half duplex.
URLs: ['Computer Networking: A Top-Down Approach, 7th Edition by James Kurose and Keith Ross', 'CCNA 200-301 Official Cert Guide, Volume 1 by Wendell Odom']

Question Text: The ____________ consists of devices and is responsible for sending signals between devices.
Choices:
a. network layer
b. data link layer
c. physical layer
d. modulation
LLM Explanation: The physical layer consists of the actual devices and media that make up the network. It is responsible for transmitting raw bits over a communication channel between devices. The physical layer defines the means of transmitting the data, including cables, cards, and physical aspects.
URLs: ['Computer Networking: A Top-Down Approach, 7th Edition by James Kurose and Keith Ross', 'CCNA 200-301 Official Cert Guide, Volume 1 by Wendell Odom']

Question Text: What is the most common type of cabling used for connecting computing devices?
Choices:
a. Power Cable
b. Twisted Pair Cable
c. VGA Cable
d. SATA Cable
LLM Explanation: Twisted pair cable is the most common type of cabling used for connecting computing devices, especially in Ethernet networks. It consists of pairs of copper wires twisted together to reduce electromagnetic interference and crosstalk. Twisted pair cables are widely used due to their low cost, flexibility, and suitability for high-speed data transmission over short to medium distances.
URLs: ['CCNA 200-301 Official Cert Guide, Volume 1 by Wendell Odom (Cisco Press, 2019)', 'Computer Networking: A Top-Down Approach by James Kurose and Keith Ross (Pearson, 2016)', 'https://www.cisco.com/c/en/us/products/switches/what-is-an-ethernet-cable.html']

Question Text: Which of the following are category types of Twisted Pair Ethernet cable? (Select all that apply)
Choices:
a. Unshielded Twisted Pair (UTP).
b. Foiled Twisted Pair (FTP).
c. Shielded Twisted Pair (STP).
d. USB Cable
LLM Explanation: The two main categories of Twisted Pair Ethernet cable are Unshielded Twisted Pair (UTP) and Shielded Twisted Pair (STP). UTP is the most common type used in Ethernet networks. It does not have any foil or braided shielding. STP, on the other hand, includes a layer of shielding (usually foil) around each pair of wires or around the entire cable to better protect against electromagnetic interference. Foiled Twisted Pair (FTP) is not a standard category, and USB Cable is a different type of cable used for connecting peripherals, not Ethernet networking.
URLs: ['CCNA 200-301 Official Cert Guide, Volume 1 by Wendell Odom (Chapter 3: Fundamentals of LANs and Ethernet LANs)', 'Network+ Guide to Networks by Jill West, Tamara Dean, Jean Andrews (Chapter 4: Network Media - Copper Cable Media)']

Question Text: How many octets are there in a MAC address?
LLM Explanation: A MAC (Media Access Control) address is a unique identifier assigned to a network interface controller (NIC) for use as a network address in communications within a network segment. A MAC address is 48 bits (6 bytes) in length and is usually represented in hexadecimal notation, with each octet separated by colons or hyphens, e.g., 00:11:22:33:44:55 or 00-11-22-33-44-55. Since each octet is 8 bits, and there are 6 octets total, a MAC address contains 6 octets.
URLs: ['https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/MAC_address', 'https://www.webopedia.com/definitions/mac-address/']

Question Text: What address is used for Ethernet broadcasts?
LLM Explanation: The Ethernet broadcast address is FF:FF:FF:FF:FF:FF. This is a special MAC address used to send Ethernet frames to all devices on a LAN segment. When a frame is sent to this address, all devices on that segment will receive and process it.
URLs: ['CCNA 200-301 Official Cert Guide, Volume 1, Chapter 2: Fundamentals of Ethernet LANs', 'IEEE 802.3 Ethernet Standard', 'https://www.cisco.com/c/en/us/support/docs/ip/routing-information-protocol-rip/13788-3.html']

Question Text: What is a cyclical redundancy check?
Choices:
a. A way for two computers to synchronize their clocks.
b. The actual data being transported by an Ethernet frame.
c. A technique that allows for multiple logical LANs to operate on the same equipment.
d. A mathematical calculation used to ensure that all data arrived intact.
LLM Explanation: A cyclical redundancy check (CRC) is a mathematical calculation used to ensure that all data arrived intact during transmission. It is an error-detecting code commonly used in digital networks and storage devices to detect accidental changes to raw data. The sending device calculates a CRC value based on the data being sent and appends it to the transmission. The receiving end then performs the same calculation on the received data and compares the calculated CRC value with the one received. If they match, it indicates the data likely arrived intact without errors.
URLs: ['https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cyclic_redundancy_check', 'https://www.techtarget.com/searchnetworking/definition/cyclic-redundancy-checking']

Question Text: Which of the following are ways for transmitting data at the Ethernet level? (Select all that apply)
Choices:
a. Multicast
b. Duplex
c. Broadcast
d. Unicast
LLM Explanation: At the Ethernet level, data can be transmitted in three ways:a. Multicast - sending data to a group of destination addresses simultaneously c. Broadcast - sending data to all nodes on the networkd. Unicast - sending data to a single destination addressDuplex (b) refers to the communication mode (half-duplex or full-duplex) and is not a way of transmitting data itself.
URLs: ['https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ethernet', 'https://www.cisco.com/c/en/us/products/switches/what-is-ethernet.html', 'https://www.computernetworkingnotes.com/ccna-study-guide/unicast-broadcast-and-multicast-addresses-explained.html']

Question Text: Which of the following are parts of an Ethernet frame? (Select all that apply)
Choices:
a. Broadcast
b. Data payload
c. EtherType field
d. Preamble
LLM Explanation: An Ethernet frame consists of several parts, including:b. Data payload - The actual data being transmitted, which can be up to 1500 bytes.  c. EtherType field - A two-byte field used to indicate which protocol is encapsulated in the payload.d. Preamble - A 7-byte field used for synchronization between the sending and receiving devices.'Broadcast' is not a specific part of the Ethernet frame structure, though frames can be sent to the broadcast MAC address.
URLs: ['https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ethernet_frame', 'https://www.cisco.com/c/en/us/support/docs/lan-switching/8021q/17056-741-4.html']
